importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the ongoing dispute over the return of deceased hostages following a ceasefire agreement, highlighting the continued tension in the Israel-Hamas conflict.
This date marks the start of the Hamas attack on Israel, which initiated the conflict and remains a foundational reference point for the current ceasefire and hostage issues.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame spans the duration of the Israel-Hamas conflict, including the ceasefire agreement and the ongoing struggle over hostage bodies, illustrating a prolonged geopolitical struggle.

keyTakeAways: Israel and Hamas agreed to a ceasefire in October 2025, with Hamas releasing 20 living hostages and Israel releasing over 1,700 Palestinian detainees and 250 prisoners.
Hamas has released only the remains of nine of the 28 deceased hostages, sparking a dispute with Israel over the locations of the remaining bodies.
Israel believes Hamas has access to at least six missing bodies, with five confirmed missing and others disputed, and claims it has intelligence on some body locations.
The United States does not believe Hamas is violating its commitments and is working through mediators to assist in locating bodies, including with support from Turkey.
A dispute over humanitarian aid restrictions has emerged, with Israel initially threatening to restrict aid to pressure Hamas, but later scaling back to comply with ceasefire terms.
The Hostages and Missing Families Forum demands that Hamas return all hostages, calling any compromise that delays the return a 'grave moral and leadership failure'.
Netanyahu reaffirmed that the 'struggle is not over' and pledged to complete the victory, emphasizing continued military presence and unresolved conditions in the ceasefire.
Key unresolved issues include Hamas disarming and Israel’s withdrawal from Gaza, which remain pending in the ceasefire agreement.
US President Donald Trump has indicated he may allow military action in Gaza if Hamas fails to uphold its end of the ceasefire deal.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Netanyahu is central to the political leadership of Israel and has publicly maintained that the 'struggle is not over,' reinforcing the nation's stance on continuing military and diplomatic efforts against Hamas.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is the primary antagonist in the conflict and is directly involved in holding hostages and negotiating the ceasefire, making it central to the dispute over body returns and prisoner exchanges.

namedEntities.name: Hamas al-Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The al-Qassam Brigades have stated they have released all living captives and the bodies they could access, asserting compliance with the ceasefire agreement but denying access to remaining bodies.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US brokered the ceasefire agreement and is now actively supporting efforts to locate missing bodies, demonstrating its role in mediating international conflict and maintaining stability.

namedEntities.name: Turkey
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Turkey has proposed sending body-retrieval specialists with earthquake recovery expertise, showing its involvement in humanitarian and logistical efforts to locate missing bodies.

namedEntities.name: United Nations
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The UN has raised concerns about humanitarian aid being used as a bargaining tool, emphasizing that aid delivery is a legal obligation and not a political leverage.

namedEntities.name: Hostages and Missing Families Forum
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This group demands that Hamas return all hostages and criticizes the Israeli government for not enforcing the full terms of the ceasefire, adding moral and public pressure on Israel.

namedEntities.name: Mount Herzl Cemetery
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This site is where Netanyahu delivered a public speech to commemorate fallen soldiers and reaffirm Israel’s commitment to the war effort, symbolizing national mourning and resolve.

namedEntities.name: Kerem Shalom Crossing
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The majority of humanitarian aid trucks entered Gaza via Kerem Shalom, illustrating the logistical route of aid and the focus of ceasefire compliance.

namedEntities.name: Kissufim
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A smaller number of aid trucks entered via Kissufim, indicating limited access to central Gaza and potential difficulties in humanitarian supply.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump has expressed willingness to allow military action in Gaza if Hamas fails to uphold the ceasefire, showing the US political leadership's conditional support for Israel’s military strategy.

namedEntities.name: COGAT
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: COGAT oversees logistics of aid and movement into Gaza and provided data on truck crossings, confirming the operational aspects of the ceasefire agreement.

namedEntities.name: October 7, 2023
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Date of Hamas attack on Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This date marks the origin of the conflict and is referenced as the starting point of the current struggle and the anniversary commemorated by Netanyahu.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Following a ceasefire agreement brokered by the United States, Egypt, Qatar, and Turkey, Israel and Hamas exchanged prisoners — with Hamas releasing 20 living hostages and Israel releasing over 1,700 Palestinian detainees — but a major dispute remains over the return of deceased hostages. Hamas has only delivered the remains of nine of the 28 deceased hostages, leading Israel to believe Hamas possesses at least six more bodies. Israel asserts it has intelligence on missing bodies and is working with the US and Turkey to locate them. The United States does not consider Hamas in violation of the agreement and is providing logistical support. Humanitarian aid restrictions were threatened but reversed, with aid now flowing as per ceasefire terms. The Hostages and Missing Families Forum demands full compliance with hostage return obligations. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reiterated that the 'struggle is not over,' pledging to complete victory and maintain military presence, while key issues like Hamas disarmament and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza remain unresolved.
title: Netanyahu says ‘struggle is not over’ as dispute with Hamas over hostage bodies continues
